FX

BoC said that progress was made on inflation and wages, while it reaffirmed the view that higher rates will be needed over time. However, the BoC also stated that accommodation will be needed to keep inflation on track and it lowered its Q1 Real GDP forecasts to 2.2% from 2.7%. Furthermore, BoC Governor Poloz said interest rates may need to remain below the neutral range and that the increase in inflation strengthens outlook but uncertainty remains over wages.


COMMODITIES

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump reportedly told Russian officials not to expect any new sanctions. (Newswires)

The US is looking to end denuclearisation with North Korea by 2020. (Nikkei)


US

Fed Beige Book said the economy continues to expand at modest-to-moderate pace, while it added that employment growth continues, labour markets were tight and that shortages of skills were reported. Furthermore, it stated that wage growth was modest and that prices increased across districts at a moderate pace, while it also mentioned that manufacturers, agriculture and transportation sectors expressed concerns about newly imposed tariffs. (Newswires)

US was reported to be targeting a NAFTA deal in 3 weeks, according to sources. (Newswires)

Fed’s Dudley (voter, neutral) said he supports only gradual hikes given that inflation sits below target. (Newswires)

Fed’s Quarles (voter, neutral) said he does not view current yield curve flattening as a signal for a recession. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Trade in the S&P 500 Emini was contained near levels seen at the tail-end of trade on Tuesday (2700-2710), though we did top yesterday’s high. Sector specifics were led by materials and energy as the commodity complex was higher across the board on Wednesday. On the flipside, consumer staples underperformed, being a defence sector as macro tensions continue to ease. In a day of low volume, Intuitive Surgical & CSX Corp. (CSX) were among the top gainers on Wednesdays session both from a strong earnings report, both beating on the top and bottom line. However, hampering the SPX, IBM (IBM) and Lam Research (LRCX). IBM did beat on both EPS & revenue (reported after market on Tuesday), but its operating gross profit margin was lower than its previous quarter. Lam Research saw a strong earnings report, beating both top & bottom line but traders seemed to be more concerned about the outlook on chip shipments which hampered fellow chip name, Applied Materials (AMAT), closing among the underperformers in the SPX & NDX. In M&A News today focus returned to AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX) as pre-market reports stated lawyers thought the companies had gained an edge in the merger trial as they managed to expose some weakness in the Trump administration's lawsuit. Further, reports in hours from FBN's Gasparino stated that the judge appears to be siding with AT&T to approve the merger as TWX CEO gave his testimony. SPX +0.1% at 2709, NDX +0.25% at 6833, DJI -0.16% at 24748.

The yield curve bear-flattened during the session, with most of the action concentrated in the belly of the curve, where yields on 5s and 7s yield rose by c.5bps, pushing 5s30s under 30bps. There were fresh cyclical highs for the 2yr yield which sent the US/German 2yr spread above 300bps, the widest since 1989. The flattening of the curve has not gone unnoticed by policy makers, Fed’s Bullard again warned the risks of a yield curve inversion could be seen within 6 months and said the Fed should have discussions on the subject. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 13+ lower at 120-04+.

US MARKET WRAP 18 April 2018: NAFTA progress, BOC hold, Saudis want oil higher
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks up, USD up, treasuries down, oil up
* REAR-VIEW: US working towards NAFTA deal in three weeks; BOC holds but tone was balanced; Turkey announces elections.
* AHEAD: NZ inflation (AMC), Aussie labour market data (overnight), Thursday Fedspeak (Quarles after market, Mester), Thursday BOE speak (Carney, Cunliffe, Broadbent).

* TRADE WARS:  Russian President Putin is said to be seeking a deal with US President Trump, and is reportedly “ready for deep concessions,” which followed news from Russia’s TASS news, which reported that the White House informed Russia that no new sanctions will be imposed 'for now'. US President Trump has also stated his aim to shrink the US trade deficit with Japan and to hopefully reach a balance. Elsewhere, reports suggested that the EU will not enter in trade talks with the US before receiving tariffs exemption. Earlier on Wednesday, the US Commerce Department launched probe on imports of some types of steel wheels from China, while it was also said to have made a preliminary finding that aluminium sheet imports from China benefit from unfair subsidies.

* GEOPOLITICS:  The US is looking to de-nuclearise North Korea by 2020, Nikkei said.  

* BOC: Rates were left unchanged at 1.25%, as expected, with the Bank reiterating its cautious approach and data-dependency; it trimmed growth forecasts for Q1, but there were some upward revisions to its growth and CPI projections for the for the rest of 2018. In the post-meeting press conference, Governor Poloz warned that rates may need to remain below the neutral range, which lent further weakness to CAD.  There seems to be a debate over how the meeting should be interpreted, with Scotiabank suggesting there was, in fact, a moderately hawkish bias, despite the dovish market response: the BoC clearly signalled that it has more confidence in a firmer wage and inflation outlook; two the opening statement to the press conference was balanced in many respects but netted out to say “It is the view of Governing Council that the need for a negative real policy rate continues to diminish steadily, albeit gradually”; third, the neutral nominal policy rate was left unchanged at 3% as the mid-point of a 2.5–3.5% target range. That keeps it essentially on top of the FOMC’s median estimate of the US nominal neutral policy rate; fourth, markets are forgetting a basic lesson about interpreting BoC communications especially given this central bank doesn’t provide formal rate guidance. Those forecasts embed the BoC’s assumed rate trajectory; fifth, the forecast details support a policy path that points to further rate hikes.

* FEDSPEAK: The Fed’s latest Beige Book noted that the US economy continues to expand at modest-to-moderate pace; manufacturers, agriculture businesses and the transportation sectors expressed concerns about newly imposed tariffs; price pressures were moderate, with steel prices rising due to new tariffs; employment growth continues, labour markets tight, shortages of skills reported, and wage growth was modest. Fed’s Dudley (voter, outgoing) made the case for gradual hikes, arguing that the FOMC must bring rates to neutral levels, which he estimated around 3.00%. Dudley sees inflation rising towards target slowly, and sees US monetary policy becoming more restrictive in the years ahead. NOTE, previously Dudley has endorsed between 3-4 hikes in 2018. Non-voter Kaplan – who has been on the wires quite regularly post the Fed’s March meeting – reiterated his view for a total of three rate rises in 2018 (implying two further hikes this year). Uber-dove Bullard (non-voter) repeated his cautious views to business television on Wednesday, taking time to again warn of possible yield curve inversion (it could happen within six months, Bullard said), and suggested the Fed would need to feature the subject into its policy debate.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.1% at 2709, NDX +0.25% at 6833, DJI -0.16% at 24748 SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY):  +0.69%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.72%, ENERGY (XLE): +2.07%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -0.22%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.09%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.12%, MATERIALS (XLB): +0.83%, TECH (XLK): -0.09%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.50%, UTLITIES (XLU): -0.10%. Trade in the S&P 500 Emini was subdued, and contained near levels seen at the tail-end of trade on Tuesday (2700-2710), though we did top yesterday’s high. Sector specifics were led by materials and energy as the commodity complex was higher across the board on Wednesday. On the flipside, consumer staples underperformed, being a defence sector as macro tensions continue to ease. In a day of low volume, Intuitive Surgical & CSX Corp. (CSX) were among the top gainers on Wednesdays session both from a strong earnings report, both beating on the top and bottom line. However, hampering the SPX, IBM (IBM) and Lam Research (LRCX). IBM did beat on both EPS & revenue (reported after market on Tuesday), but its operating gross profit margin was lower than its previous quarter. Lam Research saw a strong earnings report, beating both top & bottom line but traders seemed to be more concerned about the outlook on chip shipments which hampered fellow chip name, Applied Materials (AMAT), closing among the underperformers in the SPX & NDX. In M&A News today focus returned to AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX) as pre-market reports stated lawyers thought the companies had gained an edge in the merger trial as they managed to expose some weakness in the Trump administration's lawsuit. Further, reports in hours from FBN's Gasparino stated that the judge appears to be siding with AT&T to approve the merger as TWX CEO gave his testimony.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle up by USD 1.95 at USD 68.47/bbl, Brent futures settle up by USD 1.90 at USD 73.48/bbl. Oil prices climbed on Wednesday after the DoE reported a smaller than expected decline in US crude inventories as well as draws in every other components. Prices also were supported after JODI reported Saudi Arabia’s oil production at 9.935mln BPD (Prev. 9.983mln BPD) and exports at 7.251mln BPD (Prev. 7.17mln BPD) as well as after three sources stated the country had stretched its last week’s view on oil prices from USD 80/bbl to USD 80-100/bbl range. Finally, the UAE  hopes to involve more producers in the supply cuts deal were also bullish for crude.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 13+ lower at 120-04+. The yield curve bear-flattened during the session, with most of the action concentrated in the belly of the curve, where yields on 5s and 7s yield rose by c.5bps, pushing 5s30s under 30bps. There were fresh cyclical highs for the 2yr yield which sent the US/German 2yr spread above 300bps, the widest since 1989. The flattening of the curve has not gone unnoticed by policy makers, Fed’s Bullard again warned the risks of a yield curve inversion could be seen within 6 months and said the Fed should have discussions on the subject.

* FOREX: GBP was off worst levels, but still among the worst G10 performers as considerably weaker than expected UK CPI slightly undermines May BoE hike prospects and threatens Sterling’s seasonal bull run (to recap, Cable has rallied every April for the past 13 years). GBPUSD currently trading on both sides 1.4200 vs a circa 1.4175 post-data base and the new post-Brexit vote peak around 1.4375 posted only yesterday. CAD was another net loser on the day after some choppy trade ahead of the BoC, with the Loonie ultimately weakening from sub-1.2550 vs the Greenback to 1.2630+ and very close to mega option expiries between 1.2585-1.2600 (circa 3 bn) at the NY cut. Rates were left unchanged as widely expected, but the near term growth outlook was radically downgraded amidst NAFTA and global trade dispute uncertainty. In sum, policy will remain data dependent and the stance is still cautious. EUR was more resistant than the Pound after a downward tweak to headline Eurozone inflation in the final release, as other price metrics were relatively firm and the ECB is not expected to alter policy or guidance materially next week. EURUSD briefly dipped below 1.2350, but has recovered since towards 1.2400 again, while EURGBP remains above 0.8700 on the unsupportive Sterling factors mentioned above. Mixed performances for AUDNZD as the cross climbs over 1.0600 and AUDUSD bounces off technical support around 0.7750, but NZDUSD treads cautiously ahead of NZ Q1 CPI tonight in a 0.7300-50 range. USDJPY locked in a very tight band just above 107.00, but USDCHF seeing a bit more price action within 0.9650-0.9700 trading parameters as the Franc gains some traction – EURCHF slipping back after the old 1.2000 floor capped its advances. Political developments and an early date for Turkish elections (June 24) boosted the Lira against the Dollar resulting as the outperformer in the EM currency bloc, with USDTRY testing chart support around 4.0300 ahead of obvious psychological interest at 4.0000 having been at 4.1900+ recently.  Peso weakened against the Dollar after BoC deputy govern suggested NAFTA risks still remains putting the peso against the key EM underperformers, but then reversed losses after sources reported a NAFTA deal could be reached in 3 weeks. Also eyeing a key/big figure level vs the Dollar (18.0000) amidst pro-NAFTA comments from Mexico’s Presidential candidate front-runner, and ahead of a meeting in the US on Thursday.

EU BONDS: Bunds at pivotal point in tech terms?
content: The retracement in 10 year benchmarks has slowed significantly, but Bunds are now around a key technical level on some charts (159.16) as intraday longs are likely to have liquidated positions once the early Eurex low (159.26) was breached. So, a more neutral base and the potential to re-test psychological support at 159.00 ahead of Tuesday’s 158.95 session base. Gilts still holding up better for the well documented macro reasons, but US Treasuries also succumbing to more downside ahead of the Wall Street open, a bevvy of Fed speakers and the latest Beige Book.

EU DEBT LATEST: marked downside and less divergence
content: Bonds have pulled back quite sharply from best levels, with Bunds actually reversing all earlier gains and more to a new Eurex session low at 159.20 (-14 ticks vs +19 ticks at best), despite a softer than forecast final Eurozone CPI read and a solid 10 year German auction. However, Gilts have reversed even further to stand around ¼ point ahead vs +88 ticks at the post-UK inflation data pinnacle with the move perhaps overdone as May BoE rate expectations remain firmly in favour of a hike, albeit not as strong as they were. Core Eurozone debt may also be seeing some pressure from further outperformance at the margins, ie Italian BTPs and Spanish Bonos, while US stock futures point to an extension of Tuesday’s Wall Street gains and fixed could be bracing for a bout of asset-switching.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th April 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities mostly higher, taking the lead from Asian and Wall St. with all major bourses in the green (Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%) as earnings come into focus.
  • FTSE 100 outperforms as cable has now lost another big figure level (1.4200) in wake of considerably weaker than forecast CPI data
  • Looking ahead, highlights include NZ inflation, BoC rate decision, DoEs and a slew of central bank speakers

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from Wall St where sentiment was lifted by encouraging earnings; gains were led by the Nasdaq after Netflix shares surged on strong subscriber numbers. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive but with upside capped by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid an ongoing Banking Royal Commission grilling and after CYBG flagged a GBP 202mln pre-tax charge, while Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) outperformance was fuelled by a weaker JPY. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) were underpinned at the open in reaction to the PBoC’s surprise 100bps RRR cut for most banks and a CNY 150bln Reverse Repo operation. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as safe-haven outflows from the increased risk appetite in Japan was counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1-10yr JGBs, while USTs were lower overnight with yields in the short-end higher in which 2yr yields rose to 2.400% for the first time since 2008.

US Commerce Department launched probe on imports of some types of steel wheels from China, while it was also said to have made a preliminary finding that aluminium sheet imports from China benefit from unfair subsidies. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 150bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2817 (Prev. 6.2771)

Chinese House Prices YY (Mar) 4.9% (Prev. 5.2%). (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen (Mar) 797.3B vs. Exp. 499.2B (Prev. 3.4B, Rev. 2.6B)

Japanese Exports YY (Mar) 2.1% vs. Exp. 5.2% (Prev. 1.8%

Japanese Imports YY (Mar) -0.6%% vs. Exp. 6.3% (Prev. 16.5%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said rates can be raised gradually without risk of a surge in inflation. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dove) said goal for policy should be to get to a more neutral stance, while he added the US economy is in a good place and that he expects to see a build to inflation. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

The Russian Embassy in the US notified that no sanctions are coming. (RIA)

US President Trump said US has had discussions with North Korea at high levels, while there were separate reports that Secretary of State nominee Pompeo met with North Korean Leader Kim Jong-Un over the Easter weekend. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May is reportedly set to lose a key Brexit vote in the House of Commons in which 10 rebel Conservative MPs signed an amendment to the government's customs bill that would put securing a post-Brexit customs union with EU its main priority. (Times) Note, the vote is separate from an amendment on the customs union in the government’s withdrawal bill that will be voted on in the House of Lords today.

EU's Tusk is seeing positive momentum from Brexit negotiations, however urges UK to help solve Irish border issue. (Newswires)

Italian President Mattarella has given Senate President Casellati the mandate to explore a 5SM/centre-right government and has until Friday to report back to him. (Newswires)

 

UK CPI YY (Mar) 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.7%) (Newswires)

UK Core CPI YY (Mar) 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.4%)

EU CPI Final YY (Mar) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.4%)

EU Core CPI Final YY (Mar) 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)

EQUITIES

The European equities have taken the lead from Asian and Wall St. with all major bourses in the green (Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%) as earnings come into focus. The FTSE 100 is outperforming, fuelled by the weaker sterling as the UK inflation rate drops to the lowest in a year. Almost all sectors are resting in the green, with materials outperforming on the firmer base metal prices while consumer discretionary lagging behind. In terms of stock specifics, Hammerson (+2.4%) shares are higher following a withdrawal from the proposed acquisition of Intu Properties (-3.5%). Danone (+2.3%) is dominating the CAC 40 following strong earnings and maintaining 2018 guidance. Further for the CAC, Total (+0.8%) are also a top performer in French index amid reports the company is in talks to purchase Direct Energie (+30.5%), which in turn is soaring. Elsewhere, Germany’s Continental (-4.3%) shares dropped following a negative change in their 2018 outlook. Michelin (-3.5%) and Pirelli (-1.9%) fell in sympathy

FX

DXY

Underpinned around 89.500 after Tuesday’s broadly better than expected US data and some hawkish-leaning Fed commentary, while US-China/Russia tensions remain relatively contained after latest reports that the White House is not in the process of imposing more sanctions against Moscow, although it is purportedly looking at additional Chinese imports from an unfair competitive angle. However, the index is still looking rangy between 89.700-400 and 90.000-89.000 outside of that.

GBP

Cable had already retraced further from fresh post-Brexit vote peaks (circa 1.4375) in the run up to UK inflation data, but has now lost another big figure level (1.4200) in wake of considerably weaker than forecast CPI data that could prevent the BoE from hiking rates in May. Eur/Gbp has rebounded sharply as a consequence, through 0.8650 and just over 0.8700.

NZD

Another G10 currency on the defensive ahead of inflation data, and now reversing further 0.7400 approximate peaks vs the Usd, and now only just holding above the big figure below ahead of the NZ CPI report for Q1.

JPY/CHF

The traditional safe-havens are back in sync against the backdrop of improving risk sentiment, but with Usd/Jpy still capped ahead of recent peaks and a pivotal chart area around 107.50-55 having bounced off a major tech support level on Tuesday (106.89-90). However, the Franc has lost more traction through its 200 DMA between 0.9550-60 vs the Usd and appears on track, if not intent to hit 1.2000 vs the Eur.

CAD

Only a couple of outlying hawkish calls for the upcoming BoC policy meeting vs the large consensus expecting no change, as the Loonie unwinds some of its recent gains vs the Usd and perhaps is drawn to big option expiries from 1.2585-1.2600 in some 3 bn. Currently near the bottom end of the band vs a circa 1.2525 low yesterday with the level break via options suggesting a 90 pip move on the BoC and MPR.

EUR

Eur/Usd just holding above key chart support around 1.2330 having retreated from 1.2400+ on Tuesday following an unexpected downgrade to final Eurozone CPI.

FIXED INCOME

No surprise to see UK debt rally sharply and outperform on the back of sub-forecast CPI data and the scale of the miss vs a relatively small downgrade to final Eurozone headline inflation. The 10 year benchmark hit 122.84 (+88 ticks) before topping out, while Short Sterling futures have now been as much as 8 ticks above parity as markets significantly re-price near term BoE tightening prospects and seriously question whether it will be one and done in 2018 instead of 2 hikes. Bunds tagged along, but only reached 159.55 (+19 ticks) amidst no such hawkish expectations for the ECB policy meet next week, while US Treasuries remain underwater and in re-steepening mode after the curve and spreads compressed to fresh multi-year narrows yesterday.

COMMODITIES

Oil prices continue their rise, with WTI at USD 67.10 and Brent at USD 72.08. This comes following the weekly API inventory report which despite showing a slightly narrower than expected draw in headline crude stockpiles, was accompanied by draws across all product components of the release. The rise in oil prices is further compounded by the continued narrative of middle-eastern tensions with the latest source reports suggesting that weapons inspections have been delayed in Douma, Syria amid gunfire on the site. In the metals scope, prices for aluminium surged as Rio Tinto said it could not fulfil supply contracts due to US sanctions on Rusal, adding to the squeeze seen in the aluminium sector.  Further, the US Commerce Department launched a probe on imports of some types of steel wheels from China, while it was also said to have made a preliminary finding that aluminium sheet imports from China benefit from unfair subsidies. Gold has remained flat for the day.

US API weekly crude stocks (6 Apr) -1.047M vs. Exp. -1.400M (Prev. +1.758M). (Newswires)

Eur/Gbp has rebounded sharply as a consequence, through 0.8650 and just over 0.8700.

Another G10 currency on the defensive ahead of inflation data, and now reversing further 0.7400 approximate peaks vs the Usd, and now only just holding above the big figure below ahead of the NZ CPI report for Q1.

JPY/CHF

The traditional safe-havens are back in sync against the backdrop of improving risk sentiment, but with Usd/Jpy still capped ahead of recent peaks and a pivotal chart area around 107.50-55 having bounced off a major tech support level on Tuesday (106.89-90). However, the Franc has lost more traction through its 200 DMA between 0.9550-60 vs the Usd and appears on track, if not intent to hit 1.2000 vs the Eur.

CAD

Only a couple of outlying hawkish calls for the upcoming BoC policy meeting vs the large consensus expecting no change, as the Loonie unwinds some of its recent gains vs the Usd and perhaps is drawn to big option expiries from 1.2585-1.2600 in some 3 bn. Currently near the bottom end of the band vs a circa 1.2525 low yesterday with the level break via options suggesting a 90 pip move on the BoC and MPR.

EUR

Eur/Usd just holding above key chart support around 1.2330 having retreated from 1.2400+ on Tuesday following an unexpected downgrade to final Eurozone CPI.

Fixed Income

No surprise to see UK debt rally sharply and outperform on the back of sub-forecast CPI data and the scale of the miss vs a relatively small downgrade to final Eurozone headline inflation. The 10 year benchmark hit 122.84 (+88 ticks) before topping out, while Short Sterling futures have now been as much as 8 ticks above parity as markets significantly re-price near term BoE tightening prospects and seriously question whether it will be one and done in 2018 instead of 2 hikes. Bunds tagged along, but only reached 159.55 (+19 ticks) amidst no such hawkish expectations for the ECB policy meet next week, while US Treasuries remain underwater and in re-steepening mode after the curve and spreads compressed to fresh multi-year narrows yesterday. 

Commodities

Oil prices continue their rise, with WTI at USD 67.08 and Brent at USD 72.10. This comes following the weekly API inventory report which despite showing a slightly narrower than expected draw in headline crude stockpiles, was accompanied by draws across all product components of the release. The rise in oil prices is further compounded by the continued narrative of middle-eastern tensions with the latest source reports suggesting that weapons inspections have been delayed in Douma, Syria amid gunfire on the site. In the metals scope, prices for aluminium surged as Rio Tinto said it could not fulfil supply contracts due to US sanctions on Rusal, adding to the squeeze seen in the aluminium sector.  Further, the US Commerce Department launched a probe on imports of some types of steel wheels from China, while it was also said to have made a preliminary finding that aluminium sheet imports from China benefit from unfair subsidies. Gold has remained flat for the day.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from WPP, Orange and Sanofi
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

18th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from Wall St where sentiment was lifted by encouraging earnings; gains were led by the Nasdaq after Netflix shares surged on strong subscriber numbers. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was positive but with upside capped by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid an ongoing Banking Royal Commission grilling and after CYBG flagged a GBP 202mln pre-tax charge, while Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) outperformance was fuelled by a weaker JPY. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were underpinned at the open in reaction to the PBoC’s surprise 100bps RRR cut for most banks and a CNY 150bln Reverse Repo operation. However, Chinese bourses then failed to hold on to gains with some sceptical as the PBoC also required most of the additional funds from the RRR cut to be used to pay back Medium-term Lending Facility loans, while there were also reports of US Commerce Department probes on imports of some types of Chinese steel wheels and aluminium sheet imports.

FTSE

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) - Q1 Pilbara iron ore shipments 80.3mln tons vs. Exp. 80.5mln tons (Prev. 76.7mln Y/Y). The co.'s Q1 iron ore shipments +4.7%, due to less weather disruptions and productivity improvements. Separately, the co. signalled possible changes to 2018 aluminium output following US sanctions hitting their Russian partner Rusal earlier in the month. (Newswires)

Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS LN) - The co. has passed a roadblock on its way to paying its first dividend in 11 years by coming to a GBP 3.5bln deal to fill a hole in its staff pension fund. (The Times)

WPP (WPP LN) - The co. has hired recruitment firm Russell Reynolds to search for a replacement for Sir Martin Sorrell. (The Guardian)

BROKER MOVES

WHITBREAD (WTB LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT HSBC

RIO TINTO (RIO LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

AA (AA/ LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

RWE (RWE GY) / E.ON (EOAN GY) - The German govt. does not expect power prices to rise after an asset swap between E.ON and RWE. (Newswires)

Wage talks - German unions reached a pay deal with employers to raise public sector wages in three steps and which will be backdated to March 1st. The agreement involves an average increase of 3.19% in first step, while wages will be increased 3.09% and 1.06% in the following two years. (Newswires)

CAC

Danone (BN FP) - The co.'s group sales EUR 6.085bln, +4.9% vs. exp. +4.0%. The co. says specialised nutrition +14.5% in Q1 LFL, waters +4.2%, dairy NORAM -0.2%, EU dairy improving trend but still slightly negative sales. Have maintained 2018 guidance. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Co.’s executive vice-president and CFO Jerome Contamine has plans to retire later this year. (Newswires)

Orange (ORA FP) – Co. are considering a cash bid for Voo, according to sources. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Remy Cointreau (RCO FP) – Q4 group sales +12.8% LFL to EUR 264.9mln, cognac sales +18.3% LFL. Co. says FY 2017/2018 group sales +7.2% LFL to EUR 1.127bln, cognac sales +13.2% LFL. Co. keeps guidance of growth in FY 2017/2018 current operating profit at constant FOREX and SCPOPE. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

AIRBUS (AIR FP) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

SMI

PAN EUROPE

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Co. states that most of Elliotts’ proposals are premature and unfeasible. (Newswires)

ASML (ASML NA) – Q1 revenue EUR 2.29bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.24bln, net system sales valued at EUR 1.668bln, installed base management sales at EUR 617mln. Co. guides Q2 revenue between EUR 2.5bln to EUR 2.6bln. (Newswires)

Vopak (VPK NA) – Q1 EBITDA of EUR 190mln vs. Prev. EUR 203mln. Q1 net profit attributable to ordinary shares holders EUR 73mln vs. Prev. EUR 77mln. Co. sees financial performance to be influenced by currency exchange. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

UBI BANCA (UBI IM) INITIATED WITH AN OVERWEIGHT RATING AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SCANDAVANIA

Elisa (ELISA FH) - The co. reports Q1 revenue of EUR 450mln vs. exp. EUR 445mln, EBITDA EUR 153mln vs. exp. EUR 154mln, pre-tax profit of EUR 89mln vs. exp. EUR 90.6mln. Revenue and  comparable EBITDA estimated at same level or higher than 2017. (Newswires)

US

* EQUITIES: SPX +1.06% at 2706, NDX +2.12% at 6816, DJI +0.87% at 24786

SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.64%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.47%, ENERGY (XLE): +0.78%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.40%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.88%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.03%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.32%, TECH (XLK): +2.59%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.24%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.22%. US equity futures had a gradual, upward bias in pre-market trade, but struggled with resistance just beneath the 2700, keeping the S&P 500 Emini in a tight range between 2690 and 2700. As cash trading got underway, the Emini pushed ahead but quickly ran into the next hurdle ahead of 2710, and after failing to negotiate the level, backed-off and consolidated underneath 2710.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from Wall St where sentiment was lifted by encouraging earnings
content:
• Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from Wall St where sentiment was lifted by encouraging earnings
  • USD/JPY and JPY crosses were the most active overnight and were underpinned by safe-haven outflows from JPY amid the positive risk tone across stocks
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK, EZ and NZ inflation, BoC rate decision, DoEs and a slew of central bank speakers

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from Wall St where sentiment was lifted by encouraging earnings; gains were led by the Nasdaq after Netflix shares surged on strong subscriber numbers. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was positive but with upside capped by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector amid an ongoing Banking Royal Commission grilling and after CYBG flagged a GBP 202mln pre-tax charge, while Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) outperformance was fuelled by a weaker JPY. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were underpinned at the open in reaction to the PBoC’s surprise 100bps RRR cut for most banks and a CNY 150bln Reverse Repo operation. However, Chinese bourses then failed to hold on to gains with some sceptical as the PBoC also required most of the additional funds from the RRR cut to be used to pay back Medium-term Lending Facility loans, while there were also reports of US Commerce Department probes on imports of some types of Chinese steel wheels and aluminium sheet imports. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as safe-haven outflows from the increased risk appetite in Japan was counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1-10yr JGBs, while USTs were lower overnight with yields in the short-end higher in which 2yr yields rose to 2.400% for the first time since 2008.

US Commerce Department launched probe on imports of some types of steel wheels from China, while it was also said to have made a preliminary finding that aluminium sheet imports from China benefit from unfair subsidies. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 150bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2817 (Prev. 6.2771)

Chinese House Prices YY (Mar) 4.9% (Prev. 5.2%). (Newswires)
Chinese Property Prices rose M/M in 55 out of 70 cities (Prev. 44) and rose Y/Y in 60 out of 70 cities (Prev. 59).

Nomura said PBoC RRR cut of 100bps was more prudent than expected and favoured larger banks over mid-caps, while it also suggested that it would only be equivalent to a 30bps RRR cut. Furthermore, CITIC CLSA said it expects the recent targeted RRR cut to help contain default risks. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen (Mar) 797.3B vs. Exp. 499.2B (Prev. 3.4B, Rev. 2.6B)
Japanese Exports YY (Mar) 2.1% vs. Exp. 5.2% (Prev. 1.8%
Japanese Imports YY (Mar) -0.6%% vs. Exp. 6.3% (Prev. 16.5%)

UK/EU

UK PM May is reportedly set to lose a key Brexit vote in the House of Commons in which 10 rebel Conservative MPs signed an amendment to the government's customs bill that would put securing a post-Brexit customs union with EU its main priority. (Times) Note, the vote is separate from an amendment on the customs union in the government’s withdrawal bill that will be voted on in the House of Lords today.

All of the UK government's Brexit scenarios would leave the country worse off, according to a study by think tank Global Future. (Newswires)


Brussels is issuing a slew of legal proposals on Brexit over the next 10 weeks, in a flurry of lawmaking to prepare the EU in the event of a no deal with the UK. (FT)

German unions reached a pay deal with employers to raise public sector wages in three steps and which will be backdated to March 1st. The agreement involves an average increase of 3.19% in first step, while wages will be increased 3.09% and 1.06% in the following two years. (Newswires)
FX

USD/JPY and JPY crosses were the most active overnight and were underpinned by safe-haven outflows from JPY amid the positive risk tone across stocks. Elsewhere, the remainder of currencies traded relatively quiet with the DXY stuck around 89.50, while EUR/USD and GBP/USD kept range-bound but with the latter briefly back at the 1.4300 handle as it slightly nursed losses following yesterday’s pull-back from post-referendum highs. Elsewhere, antipodeans were also uneventful due to a lack of data and catalysts to spur price action, while HKD remained near the lower end of the band despite further attempts by the HKMA to defend the peg.

Canadian Government sources stated that NAFTA nations are not in a position to say that any more chapters have been closed, while they added that the Washington meeting on Thursday is unlikely to produce any kind of announcement. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures gained overnight with support seen following the weekly API inventory report which despite showing a slightly narrower than expected draw in headline crude stockpiles, was accompanied by draws across all product components of the release. Elsewhere, gold was kept rangebound amid a stable USD overnight, while copper was choppy and pared gains alongside a deterioration of sentiment in its largest consumer China. 

US API weekly crude stocks (6 Apr) -1.047M vs. Exp. -1.400M (Prev. +1.758M). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said US has had discussions with North Korea at high levels, while there were separate reports that Secretary of State nominee Pompeo met with North Korean Leader Kim Jong-Un over the Easter weekend. (Newswires)

South Korea said it is mulling how to alter its armistice with North Korea into a more peaceful agreement. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said that additional sanctions on Russia are under consideration. (Newswires)

Saudi foreign minister said they are willing to send troops to Syria as a part of a wider coalition. (Newswires)
US

Amid thin volume on Tuesday, US Treasuries saw selling pressure at the short-end of the curve, which pushed 2yr yields up to fresh cyclical highs. However, the rest of the curve found buyers, particularly the long-end, where 30yr yields fell by c.3bps at settlement, and causing 2s30s to narrow to cyclical lows c.60bps. Most other major curves narrowed on the session with attention also on the 5s30s which was another that saw cyclical lows on Tuesday c.32bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 3 ticks higher at 120-18.

Fed Discount Rate Minutes showed 3 Fed policymakers opposed raising the discount rate (Chicago, Minneapolis, Atlanta). Furthermore, regional Fed directors noted tight labour markets, rising wages, and solid economic conditions, although some also noted uncertainty around the impact of US tax cuts. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dove) said goal for policy should be to get to a more neutral stance, while he added the US economy is in a good place and that he expects to see a build to inflation. Furthermore, Bostic commented that businesses are confused regarding the direction of US policy on trade and that he is also hearing about labour shortages everywhere. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said rates can be raised gradually without risk of a surge in inflation. (Newswires)

US President Trump said doesn't like TPP deal for US and that bilateral trade deals are more efficient and profitable. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said the Chinese are offering "constructive reaction" regarding trade disputes, while he added that the US would like to see a free trade agreement with Japan and that US President Trump and Japanese PM Abe are to discuss Japan’s exemption from steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia mostly gets tailwind from Wall St, although China underperforms despite RRR cut
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as the region gets a tailwind from Wall St where sentiment was lifted by encouraging earnings and with gains led by the Nasdaq after Netflix shares surged on strong subscriber numbers. ASX 200 (+0.3%) is positive but with weakness in the largest weighted financials sector capping upside amid an ongoing Banking Royal Commission grilling and after CYBG flagged a GBP 202mln pre-tax charge, while Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) outperformance is fuelled by a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, both Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were underpinned at the open in reaction to the PBoC’s surprise 100bps RRR cut for most banks and a CNY 150bln Reverse Repo operation. However, Chinese bourses then failed to hold on to gains as the PBoC also required most of the additional funds from the RRR cut to be used to pay back Medium-term Lending Facility loans, while there were also reports of US Commerce Department probes on imports of some types of Chinese steel wheels and that it determined aluminium sheet imports from China benefit from unfair subsidies.

In FX markets, USD/JPY and JPY crosses are the most active overnight and are higher on safe-haven outflows from JPY amid the positive risk tone across stocks. Elsewhere, the remainder of currencies are relatively quiet with the DXY stuck around 89.50, while EUR/USD and GBP/USD are range-bound but with the latter back at the 1.4300 handle as it nurses losses following yesterday’s pull-back from post-referendum highs. Elsewhere, antipodeans are quiet due to a lack of data and catalysts to spur price action, while HKD remains near the lower end of the band despite further attempts by the HKMA to defend the peg.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat as safe-haven outflows from the increased risk appetite in Japan, is counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1-10yr JGBs, while USTs were lower overnight with yields in the short-end rising to push 2yr yields to 2.400% for the first time since 2008.

RRR Cut
